content.description:
This climb is pure joy from bottom to top, with a very endurance based, pumpy character. The climbing is interesting all the way, with the crux only slightly harder than the rest of the route. The climbing style is technical, rewarding good technique, conservation of energy and footwork over strength.

It begins to the right of the first boltt, staying to the right until the fifth bolt, where you traverse left to a beautiful rest before entering the techy second half, staying just to the right of the arete. 

Consider stick clipping the first bolt, it's a little ways up to avoid the roof and poor rock quality at the bottom.

The feeling of exposure is wonderful, and the view from the top spectacular.



Found about 150m to the North of the access gully for Longwall Right. We have pushed in and cleaned up access trails to the top and bottom. 

To access the bottom of the climb, start at the gully and turn immediately North (left) along the base of the cliff. Beware the patch of poison ivy at the start of this trail. Follow the access trail along the bottom of the cliff for ~150m, past the amphitheatre with other bolted climbs, to the prominent open area and arete of Buteo. 

To access from the top of the climb, walk up the gully and turn immediately North (left) to follow the access trail. Climb the small cliff using the red rope and continue to another scramble, also protected by a red rope. After this, continue straight ~100m until the trail turns left. This would be the second left, the first left leads to the top of Nuthatch, etc. There is an access trail from Nuthatch directly along the top to Buteo as well, so all is not lost if you take a wrong turn.

Look for the single chain at the top, used to safely access the anchor on the face and set for top rope. 

11 bolts, 2 bolt anchor with rap rings. No extendable draws needed, rope drag minimal.

A challenging test-piece route, currently being projected, and will be bolted for lead in the future. In the meantime, enjoy the top rope adventure!

A powerful and sustained climb, making big moves on poor holds and side pulls. Grimace through the crux near the top to be rewarded with a beautiful crack before the anchor.



Look for two distinct lines of weakness running up the fairly blank wall to the left of Terror Bird 5.10c trad and Shrike 5.11c sport. Begin in the line of weakness (it would be overly generous to call it a crack) right of Shrike's black water-stained start. Continue up, eventually moving leftward over to the second line of weakness and towards the crack in the final meters. 

The top is accessible by following directions for the top of The Aviary. A photo of the top will be provided.

2 glue in anchors up top.

A beautiful line of perfect laybacking on juggy flakes and stellar stems leads to a roof inside a blank corner. Transfer out left to the face and begin the crimpy and tricky final boulder problem in the last 6 meters to reach the anchors. Spotted by Amanda Ross while climbing at The Aviary, who proceeded to scrub and trundle until an absolute jungle gym of a climb was left. 

There is a single semi detatched block wedged around bolt ~9. This has been pried with a large crowbar and doesn't appear to be going anywhere/removable. Still, best to hug this beautiful rest spot gingerly.

The climb is mostly 5.10b/c until the boulder section at the top, and is very generously bolted. It would make a great lead for someone looking to stretch themselves at the grade.



The line of bolts on the left side of the Aviary amphitheatre, directly to the right of Nuthatch. See image with Topo on Aviary page.


15 bolts, 2 bolt anchor with chains and rap rings. The bolt line is almost perfectly straight, no alpine draws needed.

climbs.name: Nuthatch
climbs.fa: Cody Cook, Jared Miller, May 2022. FFA Jared Miller, Cody Cook, May 2022

content.description:
A complete adventure from bottom to top. A mix of interesting mantles, a perfect handjam roof move, stemming, slopers, pinches and lots of rests to figure it all out. The route is well protected and so varied in climbing style. 

The first bolt can be stick clipped, making the start a little safer. Scramble up the little dirty boulder to the left of the first bolt, and mantle up onto the large ledge, keeping your balance. Once you're up and have clipped the second bolt, the climbing starts in earnest. Find the best holds as you navigate up the weathered weakness in the rock, pushing past the crux to the amazing ledge for a rest above. Enjoy the super fun second half, that turns to stemming and some crack moves as you stay nice and snug in the wedge to the top. Or use the face holds and crimps only for a harder variation.

Some of the clipping is a little awkward in the last third, but the bolts were placed to make falls much safer without getting cheese-grated in the wedge.

Continue to the top, clipping the anchors (rap rings on chains to glue-ins). There's another glue-in and chain further up to make topping out or setting for top rope safer. 



Walk along the bottom of the access trail (left before going up the scramble gully) until you arrive in the large amphitheatre. Look for the roof ledge at the far left and the first bolt on the face below the ledge. 

If accessing the top: Head up the scramble, turn immidiately left and walk up the small cliff using the red rope. Continue to the second scramble with the red rope. Continue straight down the trail and look for a turn on your left. Take this trail down to the cliff top. Once you enter the open area at the top of the cliff, the anchors will be on the face, on teh right hand side, below a large flat rock. Look for the chain above the anchors, used to safely set up top rope.


13 bolts, 2 bolt chain anchor with rap rings.

climbs.name: Shrike
climbs.fa: Jared Miller, August 2022. FFA Jared Miller, October 2022

content.description:
A long and sustained adventure up to an overhanging roof of the Aviary. Pulling off the onsight would require technical skill, endurance and excellent route reading at the grade. 

Begin to the right of the line of bolts, up the black streaked water stain. Climb up the white streaked walls, using technical movements and route reading to keep your pump down. Traverse left of the bolt line and make your way up to a flaring finger to thin hands crack. Power through this to below the series of roofs. Look up and make a plan before pulling up and over the tricky roof. Continue past the inverted stepped roofs to the anchors.

Some of the best and most varied movement and climbing encountered at the grade. A pleasure to repeat over and over again. Easy to set top rope.



The series of bolts immediately right of Chickadee 5.11a, left of (currently top rope only) Cassowary 5.12+

16 bolts, 2 bolt anchor with chains & rap rings.

climbs.name: Terrorbird
climbs.fa: Brent M, 2022. FFA Brent M, Justin Curry, 2022

content.description:
Low crux through the hanging column leading to enjoyable crack climbing. Utilize dual cracks and exit right through the small roof with the chockstone. Continue up to the anchors. 

Avoid the deathblocks perched to the right of the anchors, they are stable but should not be climbed.

All route description info and gear provided by first ascentionist Brent Clark.



The obvious crack feature on the right wall of The Aviary. Right of Cassowary 5.12+

0.2-#4, x3 0.75, x2 #1, x2 #3, nuts. 2 bolt anchor with rap rings. Can be set top rope by rapping down from the top, using the chains equipped with rap rings above the route.

This is the latest area to be developed at Claghorn, with the goal of finding more moderate sport climbs to make Claghorn a little less intimidating to less experienced climbers. The walls are 25-30m and the views of the valley excellent, as with all of Claghorn. There is an access trail to walk to the base of the climbs, and another series of access trails to the tops of all the climbs. All climbs can be set top rope, though you'll probably want to be able to rappel, to save the time scrambling back around to the base. The sport routes are all well bolted, which means you'll need up to 16 draws to climb here. There are also some trad routes on the wall, all with bolted anchors and rap rings. Plenty more development to come, should be another few routes each season. One request is to name each route after a bird.
